newsArray.title: Aditi Ashok wins Ladies European Tour season-ending title
newsArray.description: India‚Äôs top woman golfer made a late surge to win the Andalucia Costa Del Sol Open in Spain by two shots for her fifth win on the tour
newsArray.content: Aditi Ashok showcased her game and grit, holding her nerves in the final holes to card a final round 66 and pull off an exciting two-shot victory over Dutch woman Anne Van Dam in the Andalucia Costa Del Sol Open, the year-ending tournament on the Ladies European Tour on Sunday. It has been a brilliant season for Aditi with the changes she had made to her swing clearly raising her game to another leve(Getty Images via AFP) The 25-year-old started and finished her season on LET in style, having won the opening event, the Magical Kenya Ladies Open, by nine shots in February. It is the biggest victory for the Bengaluru golfer, who pocketed a winner‚Äôs purse of ‚Ç¨ 97,500. We're now on WhatsApp. Click to join. Aditi finished on 17-under par (69, 68, 68, 66 =271), ahead of Anne (69, 71, 65, 68= 273). India‚Äôs Diksha Dagar was tied seventh at 10-under (72, 71, 68, 67= 278), though she finished third in the Race to Costa Del Sol (LET Order of Merit) rankings with Aditi, who played only eight events, fourth. Thailand‚Äôs Trichat Cheenglab won the title despite a tied 55th finish. It has been a brilliant season for Aditi with the changes she had made to her swing clearly raising her game to another level. Besides the two wins on LET this season, she was second in the Saudi Ladies International, third in the Lalla Meryem Cup, all in February, and won silver in the Hangzhou Asian Games. Tied second through the second and third rounds, Aditi trailed Dutch playing partner Anne Van Dam, a five-time winner on the LET who led by one shot until drama unfolded on the 15th hole leading to a rousing finish under the afternoon Spanish sun. Anne‚Äôs tee shot on the par-five hole veered to the right and settled amid stones next to a tree, forcing her to lay up on the fairway, find the fringe of the green with her third, and eventually saving par. Aditi, flawless from tee to green, birdied with a brilliant putt off at least 17 feet to tie for the lead. Her precision off the tee on the par-3 16th then left her with a two-footer for birdie while Anne‚Äôs tee shot spun back to 15 feet off the pin and she two-putted for par. The par-14 17th showcased Aditi‚Äôs skill and temperament. The driver off the tee and an accurate second shot left her with an 8-foot putt for birdie, which she sank. Her fourth birdie in five holes ‚Äì she had five birdies on the back nine, including three in a row from the 15th to 17th ‚Äì left her with a two-shot cushion going into the final hole. Anne was again frustrated after her 25-foot birdie attempt rolled to the left of the hole, leaving her with another par. The drama wasn‚Äôt over. On the 18th, Aditi found the fairway rough to the right and landed her second shot on the bunker, leaving her with a tricky third to get on the sloping green. Although Anne‚Äôs second shot landed nine feet off the pin, she needed a birdie and the Indian had to bogey to force a tie. But Aditi was creative with the wedge, aiming for the fringe of the green to get the ball to roll down the slope to three feet off the hole, sealing a great win. ‚ÄúI started slow and missed some birdies, but glad it picked up on the back nine,‚Äù a delighted Aditi said after receiving the winner‚Äôs trophy. ‚ÄúIt was a great battle, especially Anna when she plays well...she is a great player.‚Äù Aditi (added: ‚ÄúShe hit the trees and I made a great putt. That was the switch moment. And I made sure I had a good look at par on the 18th.‚Äù Catch all the Latest World Cup news and Live score along with India vs Australia Live Score and World Cup Schedule related updates on Hindustan Times Website and APPs SHARE THIS ARTICLE ON ABOUT THE AUTHOR N Ananthanarayanan N Ananthanarayanan has spent almost three decades with news agencies and newspapers, reporting domestic and international sport. He has a passion for writing on cricket and athletics. ...view detail Aditi Ashok

creator: 3-mob.com
newsArray.description: Zimbabwe had no kind words for his side The post WATCH: ‚ÄúWe always find new methods to fail‚Äù ‚Äì Zimbabwe captain Sikandar Raza after shock loss to Uganda first appeared on Three Men On a Boat.
newsArray.content: Zimbabwe T20 international captain Sikandar Raza has spoken after his side‚Äôs shock loss to Uganda in the ICC Men‚Äôs T20 World Cup Qualifier Africa. The loss means Zimbabwe need results to go their way elsewhere for them to get a wicket to the main tournament next year. A dejected Raza did not have any kind of words for his side, who he said seemed to find ‚Äònew methods to fail‚Äô. ‚ÄúThe standard of cricket we are playing is quite tough, and difficult for watch,‚Äù the skipper said. He said in the interview that Zimbabwe seemed to bring its standards down against lesser teams which was a worry. Watch the while interview below:

IND vs AUS 2nd T20I HIGHLIGHTS: India Beat Australia By 44 Runs, Go 2-0 Up In Five-Match Series
creator: ABP News Bureau
newsArray.description: India have beaten Australia by 44 runs in the second T20I of the five-match series at the Greenfield International Stadium in Thiruvananthapuram on Sunday (November 26). Australia won the toss and elected to bowl first in this fixture but each of India's top three batters scored half-centuries to lay a solid foundation for the Men in Blue. Yashasvi Jaiswal scored 53 off 25, Ruturaj Gaikwad scored 58 off 43 and Ishan Kishan made 52 off 32 before a handly little cameo from Rinku Singh worth 9-ball 31* that propelled them to a score of 235/4. Yashasvi Jaiswal receives the Player of the Match award for his solid opening act with the bat üëèüëè#TeamIndia complete a 44-run win over Australia in the 2nd T20I üëåüëåScorecard ‚ñ∂Ô∏è https://t.co/nwYe5nOBfk#INDvAUS | @IDFCFIRSTBank pic.twitter.com/smMRxGogSy ‚Äî BCCI (@BCCI) November 26, 2023 In the run chase, Australia lost three wickets inside the powerplay and were always behind in the second innings. The two spinners Ravi Bishnoi and Axar Patel got the early breakthroughs for the hosts before the pacers joined in. Bishnoi eventually returned with figures of 3 for 32 while Prasidh too picked 3 for 41. There was only one partnership that seemed to threaten India's strong total which was the fifth-wicket partnership worth 81 off 38 between Tim David (37 off 22) and Marcus Stoinis (45 off 25). Once India broke the partnership, the match never looked out of their grasp and they eventually completed a dominant victory.From the southernmost international cricket venue¬† in India, the series focus will now head to the easternmost international cricket venue in the country with the third match of the series set to be played at the Barsapara Stadium in Guwahati. Another commanding performance by Team India, securing a 2-0 lead in the T20I series against Australia! Kudos to our dynamic openers @ybj_19 and @Ruutu1331 for setting the stage on fire with their explosive fifties. @ishankishan51, holding his ground at number 3, played yet‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/pqGFUSM9Kj ‚Äî Jay Shah (@JayShah) November 26, 2023

newsArray.title: Bowling woes for Australia in second T20 loss to India
newsArray.description: A ragged Australian bowling display allowed the home side to plunder a mammoth 4-235 in Thiruvananthapuram.
newsArray.content: India‚Äôs top order fired on all cylinders to fashion a 44-run win over Australia to put the home side 2-0 ahead in the five-match T20 series in Thiruvananthapuram on Sunday. Put in to bat, India‚Äôs top three batters smashed rapid fifties to power the hosts to a commanding 4-235 at the Greenfield International Stadium. India‚Äôs Rinku Singh hammered 31 of nine balls at the death. Credit: Getty Images In reply, Australia failed to fully recover from a top-order collapse and managed only 9-191. Australia beat India in the final of the 50-overs World Cup earlier this month and both teams have fielded second-string squads for the T20 series. Ruturaj Gaikwad (58), Yashasvi Jaiswal (53), Ishan Khan (52) and Rinku Singh (31no off nine balls) capitalised on the tourists‚Äô waywardness with the ball. India‚Äôs total was their highest in T20s against Australia ‚Äì surpassing their previous best of 8-209 set three days ago at Visakhapatnam ‚Äì and easily the best score at Greenfield International Stadium. Australia‚Äôs Marcus Stoinis fell for 45 of 25 balls. Credit: AP Australia bowled poorly in the powerplay before regularly losing control as the dew set in early, dishing up 12 wides and a no-ball via a chest-high full-toss from Glenn Maxwell. Nathan Ellis (3-45) picked up three of the four wickets but was expensive in doing so, Sean Abbott‚Äôs three overs were dispatched for 56 and Australia‚Äôs three spinners were ineffective.

newsArray.title: Bowling woes for Australia in second T20 loss to India
newsArray.description: A ragged Australian bowling display allowed the home side to plunder a mammoth 4-235 in Thiruvananthapuram.
newsArray.content: India‚Äôs top order fired on all cylinders to fashion a 44-run win over Australia to put the home side 2-0 ahead in the five-match T20 series in Thiruvananthapuram on Sunday. Put in to bat, India‚Äôs top three batters smashed rapid fifties to power the hosts to a commanding 4-235 at the Greenfield International Stadium. India‚Äôs Rinku Singh hammered 31 of nine balls at the death. Credit: Getty Images In reply, Australia failed to fully recover from a top-order collapse and managed only 9-191. Australia beat India in the final of the 50-overs World Cup earlier this month and both teams have fielded second-string squads for the T20 series. Ruturaj Gaikwad (58), Yashasvi Jaiswal (53), Ishan Khan (52) and Rinku Singh (31no off nine balls) capitalised on the tourists‚Äô waywardness with the ball. India‚Äôs total was their highest in T20s against Australia ‚Äì surpassing their previous best of 8-209 set three days ago at Visakhapatnam ‚Äì and easily the best score at Greenfield International Stadium. Australia‚Äôs Marcus Stoinis fell for 45 of 25 balls. Credit: AP Australia bowled poorly in the powerplay before regularly losing control as the dew set in early, dishing up 12 wides and a no-ball via a chest-high full-toss from Glenn Maxwell. Nathan Ellis (3-45) picked up three of the four wickets but was expensive in doing so, Sean Abbott‚Äôs three overs were dispatched for 56 and Australia‚Äôs three spinners were ineffective. Jaiswal was the early aggressor, dominating India‚Äôs 1-77 powerplay, which was their best in T20s against Australia. The 21-year-old opener welcomed Abbott to the bowling crease by going 4-4-4-6-6 to bring up his half-century inside the fourth over. After Jaiswal miscued Ellis to Adam Zampa, Ishan Kishan took over and targeted Australia‚Äôs spinners. He raised his 50 by walloping Tanveer Sangha for back-to-back sixes before slicing a wide, off-balance, one-handed shot to Ellis in the deep. Gaikwad was the anchor of the innings, becoming the third Indian batter to move past 50. Acting captain Suryakumar Yadav, game one hero Rinku and Tilak Varma all teed off at the death, Australia‚Äôs last two overs thumped for 45. Australia faltered early in their chase and were reeling at 4-58 in the eighth over before Marcus Stoinis (45) and Tim David (37) arrested the slide. Wade made 42 not out down the order, but Australia still finished well short of their target. The teams now move to Guwahati for the third ODI on Tuesday. newsArray.content: CRICKET Southey Sayer Wairarapa Korus, captain and allrounder Ocean Bartlett, has been named in a New Zealand XI squad to play two warm-up games against the visiting Pakistani women‚Äôs team this week. The teams will play a one-day 50-0ver match tomorrow and a T20 match on Thursday, with both games at Bert Sutcliffe Oval at Lincoln. RUGBY SEVENS Wairarapa-Bush narrowly missed a place in the women‚Äôs final of the Central Zone Rugby Sevens at Massey University on Saturday. The green and reds qualified for the second vs three semifinal after a 29‚Äì5 loss to Hawke‚Äôs Bay, a 22‚Äì17 win over Whanganui, and a 39‚Äì0 loss to eventual champions Manawat≈´. That set up a semifinal with Hawke‚Äôs Bay, which Wai-Bush led until the final 24 seconds when the injury-hit side conceded a match-winning try. Wai-Bush finished third in the men‚Äôs competition, which was reduced to three teams after the late withdrawal of Whanganui on Friday night. A first-up 24‚Äì7 loss to Manawat≈´ was followed by a 49‚Äì5 defeat to Hawke‚Äôs Bay, who finished the tournament unbeaten. CRICKET The weather had the final say in the fourth round of the Bidwill Cup premier club championship, with both games abandoned without a ball being bowled. With two rounds to play, the Barbarians lead on 50 points, Inspire Living Greytown are on 39, Burger King Red Star 38, and Lansdowne have 22 points.

newsArray.title: Mohamed Salah reveals he is ‚Äòaddicted‚Äô to online chess: ‚ÄòHope to play Magnus Carlsen some day‚Äô
newsArray.description: Liverpool star Mohamed Salah has revealed that he plays online chess almost every day with random people.
newsArray.content: Liverpool star Mohamed Salah has revealed that he is an avid online chess player and wants to meet five-time world champion Magnus Carlsen. The Egyptian forward, widely rated among the best football players in the world, said that he plays chess online ‚Äúevery day, literally every day.‚Äù Salah said that he wishes to play five-time champion Carlsen some day. ‚ÄúI play chess, I am addicted to chess," said Salah on Sky Sports. He further said that he is not going to reveal the name he uses online while playing the sport but there have been a few opponents who would ask him if he is Salah himself. ‚ÄúI am not saying my name. I put my name and some other numbers so some people they ask ‚Äòare you Mo Salah,‚Äô I say ‚Äòyes,‚Äô they don‚Äôt believe it, and say ‚Äòyou are lying.‚Äô I say ‚Äòyes, I‚Äôm lying,'" he said. We're now on WhatsApp. Click to join. Salah said that he is also rated around 1400. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm good, I‚Äôm not Magnus, but I‚Äôm good. No one has a chance with Magnus. But hopefully we will play one day.‚Äù Carlsen, on the other hand, is known to be a huge fan of football and of Salah himself. The Norwegian has regularly featured Salah on his Fantasy Premier League squad that took him to the top of the game with more than 7 million players. The former world champion appeared to accept the invitation and took to X/Twitter on Sunday to respond with a simple emoji, tagging Salah. Incidentally, Salah's Liverpool teammate Trent Alexander-Arnold played Carlsen in an exhibition match in Manchester, England back in 2018. Alexander-Arnold ended up losing in 17 moves. "I've been playing chess since I was very young, and I've always enjoyed it. It's hard to find someone who wants to play as much as me," he had said. Salah further said that while he never played any other sport apart from football when he was young, he has now dabbled with other sports. "I play paddle tennis pretty well, tennis sometimes. I play golf, surprisingly. Not like a proper English guy but I play good gold for an Egyptian," he said. newsArray.title: Aditi Ashok wins Ladies European Tour season-ending title
newsArray.description: India‚Äôs top woman golfer made a late surge to win the Andalucia Costa Del Sol Open in Spain by two shots for her fifth win on the tour
newsArray.content: Aditi Ashok showcased her game and grit, holding her nerves in the final holes to card a final round 66 and pull off an exciting two-shot victory over Dutch woman Anne Van Dam in the Andalucia Costa Del Sol Open, the year-ending tournament on the Ladies European Tour on Sunday. It has been a brilliant season for Aditi with the changes she had made to her swing clearly raising her game to another leve(Getty Images via AFP) The 25-year-old started and finished her season on LET in style, having won the opening event, the Magical Kenya Ladies Open, by nine shots in February. It is the biggest victory for the Bengaluru golfer, who pocketed a winner‚Äôs purse of ‚Ç¨ 97,500. We're now on WhatsApp. Click to join. Aditi finished on 17-under par (69, 68, 68, 66 =271), ahead of Anne (69, 71, 65, 68= 273). India‚Äôs Diksha Dagar was tied seventh at 10-under (72, 71, 68, 67= 278), though she finished third in the Race to Costa Del Sol (LET Order of Merit) rankings with Aditi, who played only eight events, fourth. Thailand‚Äôs Trichat Cheenglab won the title despite a tied 55th finish. It has been a brilliant season for Aditi with the changes she had made to her swing clearly raising her game to another level. Besides the two wins on LET this season, she was second in the Saudi Ladies International, third in the Lalla Meryem Cup, all in February, and won silver in the Hangzhou Asian Games. Tied second through the second and third rounds, Aditi trailed Dutch playing partner Anne Van Dam, a five-time winner on the LET who led by one shot until drama unfolded on the 15th hole leading to a rousing finish under the afternoon Spanish sun. Anne‚Äôs tee shot on the par-five hole veered to the right and settled amid stones next to a tree, forcing her to lay up on the fairway, find the fringe of the green with her third, and eventually saving par. Aditi, flawless from tee to green, birdied with a brilliant putt off at least 17 feet to tie for the lead. Her precision off the tee on the par-3 16th then left her with a two-footer for birdie while Anne‚Äôs tee shot spun back to 15 feet off the pin and she two-putted for par. The par-14 17th showcased Aditi‚Äôs skill and temperament. The driver off the tee and an accurate second shot left her with an 8-foot putt for birdie, which she sank. Her fourth birdie in five holes ‚Äì she had five birdies on the back nine, including three in a row from the 15th to 17th ‚Äì left her with a two-shot cushion going into the final hole. Anne was again frustrated after her 25-foot birdie attempt rolled to the left of the hole, leaving her with another par. The drama wasn‚Äôt over. On the 18th, Aditi found the fairway rough to the right and landed her second shot on the bunker, leaving her with a tricky third to get on the sloping green. Although Anne‚Äôs second shot landed nine feet off the pin, she needed a birdie and the Indian had to bogey to force a tie. But Aditi was creative with the wedge, aiming for the fringe of the green to get the ball to roll down the slope to three feet off the hole, sealing a great win. ‚ÄúI started slow and missed some birdies, but glad it picked up on the back nine,‚Äù a delighted Aditi said after receiving the winner‚Äôs trophy. ‚ÄúIt was a great battle, especially Anna when she plays well...she is a great player.‚Äù Aditi (added: ‚ÄúShe hit the trees and I made a great putt. That was the switch moment. And I made sure I had a good look at par on the 18th.‚Äù Catch all the Latest World Cup news and Live score along with India vs Australia Live Score and World Cup Schedule related updates on Hindustan Times Website and APPs SHARE THIS ARTICLE ON ABOUT THE AUTHOR N Ananthanarayanan N Ananthanarayanan has spent almost three decades with news agencies and newspapers, reporting domestic and international sport. He has a passion for writing on cricket and athletics. ...view detail Aditi Ashok

newsArray.content: Zimbabwe T20 international captain Sikandar Raza has spoken after his side‚Äôs shock loss to Uganda in the ICC Men‚Äôs T20 World Cup Qualifier Africa. The loss means Zimbabwe need results to go their way elsewhere for them to get a wicket to the main tournament next year. A dejected Raza did not have any kind of words for his side, who he said seemed to find ‚Äònew methods to fail‚Äô. ‚ÄúThe standard of cricket we are playing is quite tough, and difficult for watch,‚Äù the skipper said. He said in the interview that Zimbabwe seemed to bring its standards down against lesser teams which was a worry. Watch the while interview below:

creator: ABP News Bureau
newsArray.description: India have beaten Australia by 44 runs in the second T20I of the five-match series at the Greenfield International Stadium in Thiruvananthapuram on Sunday (November 26). Australia won the toss and elected to bowl first in this fixture but each of India's top three batters scored half-centuries to lay a solid foundation for the Men in Blue. Yashasvi Jaiswal scored 53 off 25, Ruturaj Gaikwad scored 58 off 43 and Ishan Kishan made 52 off 32 before a handly little cameo from Rinku Singh worth 9-ball 31* that propelled them to a score of 235/4. Yashasvi Jaiswal receives the Player of the Match award for his solid opening act with the bat üëèüëè#TeamIndia complete a 44-run win over Australia in the 2nd T20I üëåüëåScorecard ‚ñ∂Ô∏è https://t.co/nwYe5nOBfk#INDvAUS | @IDFCFIRSTBank pic.twitter.com/smMRxGogSy ‚Äî BCCI (@BCCI) November 26, 2023 In the run chase, Australia lost three wickets inside the powerplay and were always behind in the second innings. The two spinners Ravi Bishnoi and Axar Patel got the early breakthroughs for the hosts before the pacers joined in. Bishnoi eventually returned with figures of 3 for 32 while Prasidh too picked 3 for 41. There was only one partnership that seemed to threaten India's strong total which was the fifth-wicket partnership worth 81 off 38 between Tim David (37 off 22) and Marcus Stoinis (45 off 25). Once India broke the partnership, the match never looked out of their grasp and they eventually completed a dominant victory.From the southernmost international cricket venue¬† in India, the series focus will now head to the easternmost international cricket venue in the country with the third match of the series set to be played at the Barsapara Stadium in Guwahati. Another commanding performance by Team India, securing a 2-0 lead in the T20I series against Australia! Kudos to our dynamic openers @ybj_19 and @Ruutu1331 for setting the stage on fire with their explosive fifties. @ishankishan51, holding his ground at number 3, played yet‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/pqGFUSM9Kj ‚Äî Jay Shah (@JayShah) November 26, 2023

newsArray.title: Bowling woes for Australia in second T20 loss to India
newsArray.description: A ragged Australian bowling display allowed the home side to plunder a mammoth 4-235 in Thiruvananthapuram.
newsArray.content: India‚Äôs top order fired on all cylinders to fashion a 44-run win over Australia to put the home side 2-0 ahead in the five-match T20 series in Thiruvananthapuram on Sunday. Put in to bat, India‚Äôs top three batters smashed rapid fifties to power the hosts to a commanding 4-235 at the Greenfield International Stadium. India‚Äôs Rinku Singh hammered 31 of nine balls at the death. Credit: Getty Images In reply, Australia failed to fully recover from a top-order collapse and managed only 9-191. Australia beat India in the final of the 50-overs World Cup earlier this month and both teams have fielded second-string squads for the T20 series. Ruturaj Gaikwad (58), Yashasvi Jaiswal (53), Ishan Khan (52) and Rinku Singh (31no off nine balls) capitalised on the tourists‚Äô waywardness with the ball. India‚Äôs total was their highest in T20s against Australia ‚Äì surpassing their previous best of 8-209 set three days ago at Visakhapatnam ‚Äì and easily the best score at Greenfield International Stadium. Australia‚Äôs Marcus Stoinis fell for 45 of 25 balls. Credit: AP Australia bowled poorly in the powerplay before regularly losing control as the dew set in early, dishing up 12 wides and a no-ball via a chest-high full-toss from Glenn Maxwell. Nathan Ellis (3-45) picked up three of the four wickets but was expensive in doing so, Sean Abbott‚Äôs three overs were dispatched for 56 and Australia‚Äôs three spinners were ineffective.

newsArray.title: Bowling woes for Australia in second T20 loss to India
newsArray.description: A ragged Australian bowling display allowed the home side to plunder a mammoth 4-235 in Thiruvananthapuram.
newsArray.content: India‚Äôs top order fired on all cylinders to fashion a 44-run win over Australia to put the home side 2-0 ahead in the five-match T20 series in Thiruvananthapuram on Sunday. Put in to bat, India‚Äôs top three batters smashed rapid fifties to power the hosts to a commanding 4-235 at the Greenfield International Stadium. India‚Äôs Rinku Singh hammered 31 of nine balls at the death. Credit: Getty Images In reply, Australia failed to fully recover from a top-order collapse and managed only 9-191. Australia beat India in the final of the 50-overs World Cup earlier this month and both teams have fielded second-string squads for the T20 series. Ruturaj Gaikwad (58), Yashasvi Jaiswal (53), Ishan Khan (52) and Rinku Singh (31no off nine balls) capitalised on the tourists‚Äô waywardness with the ball. India‚Äôs total was their highest in T20s against Australia ‚Äì surpassing their previous best of 8-209 set three days ago at Visakhapatnam ‚Äì and easily the best score at Greenfield International Stadium. Australia‚Äôs Marcus Stoinis fell for 45 of 25 balls. Credit: AP Australia bowled poorly in the powerplay before regularly losing control as the dew set in early, dishing up 12 wides and a no-ball via a chest-high full-toss from Glenn Maxwell. Nathan Ellis (3-45) picked up three of the four wickets but was expensive in doing so, Sean Abbott‚Äôs three overs were dispatched for 56 and Australia‚Äôs three spinners were ineffective. Jaiswal was the early aggressor, dominating India‚Äôs 1-77 powerplay, which was their best in T20s against Australia. The 21-year-old opener welcomed Abbott to the bowling crease by going 4-4-4-6-6 to bring up his half-century inside the fourth over. After Jaiswal miscued Ellis to Adam Zampa, Ishan Kishan took over and targeted Australia‚Äôs spinners. He raised his 50 by walloping Tanveer Sangha for back-to-back sixes before slicing a wide, off-balance, one-handed shot to Ellis in the deep. Gaikwad was the anchor of the innings, becoming the third Indian batter to move past 50. Acting captain Suryakumar Yadav, game one hero Rinku and Tilak Varma all teed off at the death, Australia‚Äôs last two overs thumped for 45. Australia faltered early in their chase and were reeling at 4-58 in the eighth over before Marcus Stoinis (45) and Tim David (37) arrested the slide. Wade made 42 not out down the order, but Australia still finished well short of their target. The teams now move to Guwahati for the third ODI on Tuesday. newsArray.description: CRICKET Southey Sayer Wairarapa Korus, captain and allrounder Ocean Bartlett, has been named in a New Zealand XI squad to play two warm-up games against the visiting Pakistani women‚Äôs team this week. The teams will play a one-day 50-0ver match tomorrow and a T20 match on Thursday, with both games at Bert Sutcliffe Oval at [‚Ä¶]
newsArray.content: CRICKET Southey Sayer Wairarapa Korus, captain and allrounder Ocean Bartlett, has been named in a New Zealand XI squad to play two warm-up games against the visiting Pakistani women‚Äôs team this week. The teams will play a one-day 50-0ver match tomorrow and a T20 match on Thursday, with both games at Bert Sutcliffe Oval at Lincoln. RUGBY SEVENS Wairarapa-Bush narrowly missed a place in the women‚Äôs final of the Central Zone Rugby Sevens at Massey University on Saturday. The green and reds qualified for the second vs three semifinal after a 29‚Äì5 loss to Hawke‚Äôs Bay, a 22‚Äì17 win over Whanganui, and a 39‚Äì0 loss to eventual champions Manawat≈´. That set up a semifinal with Hawke‚Äôs Bay, which Wai-Bush led until the final 24 seconds when the injury-hit side conceded a match-winning try. Wai-Bush finished third in the men‚Äôs competition, which was reduced to three teams after the late withdrawal of Whanganui on Friday night. A first-up 24‚Äì7 loss to Manawat≈´ was followed by a 49‚Äì5 defeat to Hawke‚Äôs Bay, who finished the tournament unbeaten. CRICKET The weather had the final say in the fourth round of the Bidwill Cup premier club championship, with both games abandoned without a ball being bowled. With two rounds to play, the Barbarians lead on 50 points, Inspire Living Greytown are on 39, Burger King Red Star 38, and Lansdowne have 22 points.

newsArray.title: Mohamed Salah reveals he is ‚Äòaddicted‚Äô to online chess: ‚ÄòHope to play Magnus Carlsen some day‚Äô
newsArray.description: Liverpool star Mohamed Salah has revealed that he plays online chess almost every day with random people.
newsArray.content: Liverpool star Mohamed Salah has revealed that he is an avid online chess player and wants to meet five-time world champion Magnus Carlsen. The Egyptian forward, widely rated among the best football players in the world, said that he plays chess online ‚Äúevery day, literally every day.‚Äù Salah said that he wishes to play five-time champion Carlsen some day. ‚ÄúI play chess, I am addicted to chess," said Salah on Sky Sports. He further said that he is not going to reveal the name he uses online while playing the sport but there have been a few opponents who would ask him if he is Salah himself. ‚ÄúI am not saying my name. I put my name and some other numbers so some people they ask ‚Äòare you Mo Salah,‚Äô I say ‚Äòyes,‚Äô they don‚Äôt believe it, and say ‚Äòyou are lying.‚Äô I say ‚Äòyes, I‚Äôm lying,'" he said. We're now on WhatsApp. Click to join. Salah said that he is also rated around 1400. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm good, I‚Äôm not Magnus, but I‚Äôm good. No one has a chance with Magnus. But hopefully we will play one day.‚Äù Carlsen, on the other hand, is known to be a huge fan of football and of Salah himself. The Norwegian has regularly featured Salah on his Fantasy Premier League squad that took him to the top of the game with more than 7 million players. The former world champion appeared to accept the invitation and took to X/Twitter on Sunday to respond with a simple emoji, tagging Salah. Incidentally, Salah's Liverpool teammate Trent Alexander-Arnold played Carlsen in an exhibition match in Manchester, England back in 2018. Alexander-Arnold ended up losing in 17 moves. "I've been playing chess since I was very young, and I've always enjoyed it. It's hard to find someone who wants to play as much as me," he had said. Salah further said that while he never played any other sport apart from football when he was young, he has now dabbled with other sports. "I play paddle tennis pretty well, tennis sometimes. I play golf, surprisingly. Not like a proper English guy but I play good gold for an Egyptian," he said. newsArray.title: Aditi Ashok wins Ladies European Tour season-ending title
newsArray.description: India‚Äôs top woman golfer made a late surge to win the Andalucia Costa Del Sol Open in Spain by two shots for her fifth win on the tour
newsArray.content: Aditi Ashok showcased her game and grit, holding her nerves in the final holes to card a final round 66 and pull off an exciting two-shot victory over Dutch woman Anne Van Dam in the Andalucia Costa Del Sol Open, the year-ending tournament on the Ladies European Tour on Sunday. It has been a brilliant season for Aditi with the changes she had made to her swing clearly raising her game to another leve(Getty Images via AFP) The 25-year-old started and finished her season on LET in style, having won the opening event, the Magical Kenya Ladies Open, by nine shots in February. It is the biggest victory for the Bengaluru golfer, who pocketed a winner‚Äôs purse of ‚Ç¨ 97,500. We're now on WhatsApp. Click to join. Aditi finished on 17-under par (69, 68, 68, 66 =271), ahead of Anne (69, 71, 65, 68= 273). India‚Äôs Diksha Dagar was tied seventh at 10-under (72, 71, 68, 67= 278), though she finished third in the Race to Costa Del Sol (LET Order of Merit) rankings with Aditi, who played only eight events, fourth. Thailand‚Äôs Trichat Cheenglab won the title despite a tied 55th finish. It has been a brilliant season for Aditi with the changes she had made to her swing clearly raising her game to another level. Besides the two wins on LET this season, she was second in the Saudi Ladies International, third in the Lalla Meryem Cup, all in February, and won silver in the Hangzhou Asian Games. Tied second through the second and third rounds, Aditi trailed Dutch playing partner Anne Van Dam, a five-time winner on the LET who led by one shot until drama unfolded on the 15th hole leading to a rousing finish under the afternoon Spanish sun. Anne‚Äôs tee shot on the par-five hole veered to the right and settled amid stones next to a tree, forcing her to lay up on the fairway, find the fringe of the green with her third, and eventually saving par. Aditi, flawless from tee to green, birdied with a brilliant putt off at least 17 feet to tie for the lead. Her precision off the tee on the par-3 16th then left her with a two-footer for birdie while Anne‚Äôs tee shot spun back to 15 feet off the pin and she two-putted for par. The par-14 17th showcased Aditi‚Äôs skill and temperament. The driver off the tee and an accurate second shot left her with an 8-foot putt for birdie, which she sank. Her fourth birdie in five holes ‚Äì she had five birdies on the back nine, including three in a row from the 15th to 17th ‚Äì left her with a two-shot cushion going into the final hole. Anne was again frustrated after her 25-foot birdie attempt rolled to the left of the hole, leaving her with another par. The drama wasn‚Äôt over. On the 18th, Aditi found the fairway rough to the right and landed her second shot on the bunker, leaving her with a tricky third to get on the sloping green. Although Anne‚Äôs second shot landed nine feet off the pin, she needed a birdie and the Indian had to bogey to force a tie. But Aditi was creative with the wedge, aiming for the fringe of the green to get the ball to roll down the slope to three feet off the hole, sealing a great win. ‚ÄúI started slow and missed some birdies, but glad it picked up on the back nine,‚Äù a delighted Aditi said after receiving the winner‚Äôs trophy. ‚ÄúIt was a great battle, especially Anna when she plays well...she is a great player.‚Äù Aditi (added: ‚ÄúShe hit the trees and I made a great putt. That was the switch moment. And I made sure I had a good look at par on the 18th.‚Äù Catch all the Latest World Cup news and Live score along with India vs Australia Live Score and World Cup Schedule related updates on Hindustan Times Website and APPs SHARE THIS ARTICLE ON ABOUT THE AUTHOR N Ananthanarayanan N Ananthanarayanan has spent almost three decades with news agencies and newspapers, reporting domestic and international sport. He has a passion for writing on cricket and athletics. ...view detail Aditi Ashok

newsArray.content: Zimbabwe T20 international captain Sikandar Raza has spoken after his side‚Äôs shock loss to Uganda in the ICC Men‚Äôs T20 World Cup Qualifier Africa. The loss means Zimbabwe need results to go their way elsewhere for them to get a wicket to the main tournament next year. A dejected Raza did not have any kind of words for his side, who he said seemed to find ‚Äònew methods to fail‚Äô. ‚ÄúThe standard of cricket we are playing is quite tough, and difficult for watch,‚Äù the skipper said. creator: ABP News Bureau
newsArray.description: India have beaten Australia by 44 runs in the second T20I of the five-match series at the Greenfield International Stadium in Thiruvananthapuram on Sunday (November 26). Australia won the toss and elected to bowl first in this fixture but each of India's top three batters scored half-centuries to lay a solid foundation for the Men in Blue. Yashasvi Jaiswal scored 53 off 25, Ruturaj Gaikwad scored 58 off 43 and Ishan Kishan made 52 off 32 before a handly little cameo from Rinku Singh worth 9-ball 31* that propelled them to a score of 235/4. Yashasvi Jaiswal receives the Player of the Match award for his solid opening act with the bat üëèüëè#TeamIndia complete a 44-run win over Australia in the 2nd T20I üëåüëåScorecard ‚ñ∂Ô∏è https://t.co/nwYe5nOBfk#INDvAUS | @IDFCFIRSTBank pic.twitter.com/smMRxGogSy ‚Äî BCCI (@BCCI) November 26, 2023 In the run chase, Australia lost three wickets inside the powerplay and were always behind in the second innings. The two spinners Ravi Bishnoi and Axar Patel got the early breakthroughs for the hosts before the pacers joined in. Bishnoi eventually returned with figures of 3 for 32 while Prasidh too picked 3 for 41. There was only one partnership that seemed to threaten India's strong total which was the fifth-wicket partnership worth 81 off 38 between Tim David (37 off 22) and Marcus Stoinis (45 off 25). Once India broke the partnership, the match never looked out of their grasp and they eventually completed a dominant victory.From the southernmost international cricket venue¬† in India, the series focus will now head to the easternmost international cricket venue in the country with the third match of the series set to be played at the Barsapara Stadium in Guwahati. Another commanding performance by Team India, securing a 2-0 lead in the T20I series against Australia! newsArray.title: Bowling woes for Australia in second T20 loss to India
newsArray.description: A ragged Australian bowling display allowed the home side to plunder a mammoth 4-235 in Thiruvananthapuram.
newsArray.content: India‚Äôs top order fired on all cylinders to fashion a 44-run win over Australia to put the home side 2-0 ahead in the five-match T20 series in Thiruvananthapuram on Sunday. Put in to bat, India‚Äôs top three batters smashed rapid fifties to power the hosts to a commanding 4-235 at the Greenfield International Stadium. India‚Äôs Rinku Singh hammered 31 of nine balls at the death. Credit: Getty Images In reply, Australia failed to fully recover from a top-order collapse and managed only 9-191. Australia beat India in the final of the 50-overs World Cup earlier this month and both teams have fielded second-string squads for the T20 series. Ruturaj Gaikwad (58), Yashasvi Jaiswal (53), Ishan Khan (52) and Rinku Singh (31no off nine balls) capitalised on the tourists‚Äô waywardness with the ball. India‚Äôs total was their highest in T20s against Australia ‚Äì surpassing their previous best of 8-209 set three days ago at Visakhapatnam ‚Äì and easily the best score at Greenfield International Stadium. Australia‚Äôs Marcus Stoinis fell for 45 of 25 balls. Credit: AP Australia bowled poorly in the powerplay before regularly losing control as the dew set in early, dishing up 12 wides and a no-ball via a chest-high full-toss from Glenn Maxwell. Nathan Ellis (3-45) picked up three of the four wickets but was expensive in doing so, Sean Abbott‚Äôs three overs were dispatched for 56 and Australia‚Äôs three spinners were ineffective.

newsArray.title: Bowling woes for Australia in second T20 loss to India
newsArray.description: A ragged Australian bowling display allowed the home side to plunder a mammoth 4-235 in Thiruvananthapuram.
newsArray.content: India‚Äôs top order fired on all cylinders to fashion a 44-run win over Australia to put the home side 2-0 ahead in the five-match T20 series in Thiruvananthapuram on Sunday. Put in to bat, India‚Äôs top three batters smashed rapid fifties to power the hosts to a commanding 4-235 at the Greenfield International Stadium. India‚Äôs Rinku Singh hammered 31 of nine balls at the death. Credit: Getty Images In reply, Australia failed to fully recover from a top-order collapse and managed only 9-191. Australia beat India in the final of the 50-overs World Cup earlier this month and both teams have fielded second-string squads for the T20 series. Ruturaj Gaikwad (58), Yashasvi Jaiswal (53), Ishan Khan (52) and Rinku Singh (31no off nine balls) capitalised on the tourists‚Äô waywardness with the ball. India‚Äôs total was their highest in T20s against Australia ‚Äì surpassing their previous best of 8-209 set three days ago at Visakhapatnam ‚Äì and easily the best score at Greenfield International Stadium. Australia‚Äôs Marcus Stoinis fell for 45 of 25 balls. Credit: AP Australia bowled poorly in the powerplay before regularly losing control as the dew set in early, dishing up 12 wides and a no-ball via a chest-high full-toss from Glenn Maxwell. Nathan Ellis (3-45) picked up three of the four wickets but was expensive in doing so, Sean Abbott‚Äôs three overs were dispatched for 56 and Australia‚Äôs three spinners were ineffective. Jaiswal was the early aggressor, dominating India‚Äôs 1-77 powerplay, which was their best in T20s against Australia. The 21-year-old opener welcomed Abbott to the bowling crease by going 4-4-4-6-6 to bring up his half-century inside the fourth over. After Jaiswal miscued Ellis to Adam Zampa, Ishan Kishan took over and targeted Australia‚Äôs spinners. He raised his 50 by walloping Tanveer Sangha for back-to-back sixes before slicing a wide, off-balance, one-handed shot to Ellis in the deep. Gaikwad was the anchor of the innings, becoming the third Indian batter to move past 50. Acting captain Suryakumar Yadav, game one hero Rinku and Tilak Varma all teed off at the death, Australia‚Äôs last two overs thumped for 45. Australia faltered early in their chase and were reeling at 4-58 in the eighth over before Marcus Stoinis (45) and Tim David (37) arrested the slide. Wade made 42 not out down the order, but Australia still finished well short of their target. The teams now move to Guwahati for the third ODI on Tuesday. newsArray.content: CRICKET Southey Sayer Wairarapa Korus, captain and allrounder Ocean Bartlett, has been named in a New Zealand XI squad to play two warm-up games against the visiting Pakistani women‚Äôs team this week. The teams will play a one-day 50-0ver match tomorrow and a T20 match on Thursday, with both games at Bert Sutcliffe Oval at Lincoln. RUGBY SEVENS Wairarapa-Bush narrowly missed a place in the women‚Äôs final of the Central Zone Rugby Sevens at Massey University on Saturday. The green and reds qualified for the second vs three semifinal after a 29‚Äì5 loss to Hawke‚Äôs Bay, a 22‚Äì17 win over Whanganui, and a 39‚Äì0 loss to eventual champions Manawat≈´. That set up a semifinal with Hawke‚Äôs Bay, which Wai-Bush led until the final 24 seconds when the injury-hit side conceded a match-winning try. Wai-Bush finished third in the men‚Äôs competition, which was reduced to three teams after the late withdrawal of Whanganui on Friday night. A first-up 24‚Äì7 loss to Manawat≈´ was followed by a 49‚Äì5 defeat to Hawke‚Äôs Bay, who finished the tournament unbeaten. CRICKET The weather had the final say in the fourth round of the Bidwill Cup premier club championship, with both games abandoned without a ball being bowled. With two rounds to play, the Barbarians lead on 50 points, Inspire Living Greytown are on 39, Burger King Red Star 38, and Lansdowne have 22 points.

newsArray.title: Mohamed Salah reveals he is ‚Äòaddicted‚Äô to online chess: ‚ÄòHope to play Magnus Carlsen some day‚Äô
newsArray.description: Liverpool star Mohamed Salah has revealed that he plays online chess almost every day with random people.
newsArray.content: Liverpool star Mohamed Salah has revealed that he is an avid online chess player and wants to meet five-time world champion Magnus Carlsen. The Egyptian forward, widely rated among the best football players in the world, said that he plays chess online ‚Äúevery day, literally every day.‚Äù Salah said that he wishes to play five-time champion Carlsen some day. ‚ÄúI play chess, I am addicted to chess," said Salah on Sky Sports. He further said that he is not going to reveal the name he uses online while playing the sport but there have been a few opponents who would ask him if he is Salah himself. ‚ÄúI am not saying my name. I put my name and some other numbers so some people they ask ‚Äòare you Mo Salah,‚Äô I say ‚Äòyes,‚Äô they don‚Äôt believe it, and say ‚Äòyou are lying.‚Äô I say ‚Äòyes, I‚Äôm lying,'" he said. We're now on WhatsApp. Click to join. Salah said that he is also rated around 1400. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm good, I‚Äôm not Magnus, but I‚Äôm good. No one has a chance with Magnus. But hopefully we will play one day.‚Äù Carlsen, on the other hand, is known to be a huge fan of football and of Salah himself. The Norwegian has regularly featured Salah on his Fantasy Premier League squad that took him to the top of the game with more than 7 million players. The former world champion appeared to accept the invitation and took to X/Twitter on Sunday to respond with a simple emoji, tagging Salah. Incidentally, Salah's Liverpool teammate Trent Alexander-Arnold played Carlsen in an exhibition match in Manchester, England back in 2018. Alexander-Arnold ended up losing in 17 moves. "I've been playing chess since I was very young, and I've always enjoyed it. It's hard to find someone who wants to play as much as me," he had said. Salah further said that while he never played any other sport apart from football when he was young, he has now dabbled with other sports. "I play paddle tennis pretty well, tennis sometimes. I play golf, surprisingly. Not like a proper English guy but I play good gold for an Egyptian," he said.
